Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2013 07:48AM Angelfalls wrote: When my cancer first spread to my sternum, my onc argued that this was a regional recurrence rather than mets, so that she could treat more aggressively. But I now know this was actually the first of my mets. I was treated with rads, an ooph and Arimidex which got me to NED quite quickly and kept me in his company for nearly 5 years... Then he went and left me 20 months ago and now I'm searching for the Stable Boy!

The ooph plus rads and Arimidex got me to and kept me NED for nearly 5 years, but the cancer has now come back again, even after the ooph. Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2012 03:25AM Angelfalls wrote: Welcome, Samantha, although I'm so sorry you've had to join us. My advice is to keep breathing and putting one foot in front of the other while you wait to find out more; the time spent waiting for test results and a treatment plan is probably the most difficult and most people start to feel better, or at least less anxious, once their treatment gets underway. As the previous posters have said, keep on using this site to get the information and support you need. Stay away from Google, which will just send you spinning in the direction of out-of-date stats and scary stories with no basis in reality. If you have any question, don't be embarrassed to ask it here - we've all been where you are now and know how overwhelming it can be, not just because of the diagnosis, but also because of the whole new language that will come with the treatment options. And while it's perfectly normal to want to try and protect your loved ones, try and put yourself first at this time and make sure your family are supporting you. Take care and good luck with your next appointment.

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2012 03:09PM Angelfalls wrote: I did cold cap at initial dx 9 years ago (it seems we use it more in the UK), when having 4xFEC + 4xTaxotere. Although I didn't keep all my hair, it only thinned as opposed to me going completely bald. I used scarves and hats and still had enough of a hair "halo" to feel like I didn't need to use a wig. But as with so many of our treatments, there are varying success rates and there's certainly no guarantee you won't lose all your hair, even with cold cap. Good luck with your chemo. I hope the SEs will be gentle on you and your hair. Take care, Angelfalls xx

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2012 07:47AM Angelfalls wrote: This is a really interesting thread and says so much more about each of us as people, beyond the usual results and treatment issues threads. For me, my current status would be Confidence: 50%; Hope: 95%. Although my confidence level varies wildly, depending on whether or not my treatment is working at the time: If you'd asked me 18 months ago, when I'd been NED for 4 years after a regional recurrence / mets to my sternum and internal mammary nodes, my confidence would have been right up there, too. But if you'd asked me 2 months ago, when I found out that Xeloda hadn't worked for me at all, my confidence took a real hit. But cancer has taken enough from me (breast, hair, ovaries, chance to have kids,...), so I'm not going to let it take my hope, too. I hope my tx will get me back to NED. I hope I'll have a "normal" life span, even if I die of BC at 80 (only another 40 years to go!!!). I hope my parents don't have to bury their only child. I hope my husband doesn't lose his 2nd wife to cancer (his 1st died of cervical cancer in her 30s). I hope my step-daughter doesn't have to walk that path again... And the advances we see give reason for hope all the time: When I was first diagnosed, Herceptin was just being trialled and look at the huge difference that has made to so many. The announcement only yesterday of the identification of 10 BC sub-types will mean we may all be able to access targeted drugs in the future, effectively giving us a cure for each type. What do stats mean, anyway? The odds were against me getting BC, but I got it. The odds were against it coming back, but it came back. The odds were against it spreading further, but it spread. The odds are against me dying from anything other than BC, so why the h*ll wouldn't I?!! Sorry for the long post, but I just had to share. My final hope is that our teams can just keep us all going for long enough to benefit from the advances that are surely coming. Take care, Angelfalls xx

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2012 12:12AM Angelfalls wrote: I don't have children of my own, but just wanted to share my experience of bringing up my husband's daughter who lost her mum when she was 12. She and her mum lived on the other side of the world, so we didn't see her often and contact was mainly limited to phone calls, letters and cards. My husband was thankfully able to be there for his daughter when his ex passed, which was a real relief for everyone. She has a huge extended family and was staying with one of her mum's cousins and his large family who offered to give her a home so that she could stay in a familiar environment, with friends and family and stay at the same school, etc. But that little 12 year old chose to cross the Atlantic and come to a country where we speak a different language and where she only knew her dad and me. That was 11 years ago now and she has turned into a young woman her mum would be very proud of. Although the situation is not at all the same, the point I'm trying to make is that kids are far more resilient than we think. They also may feel the pull of family ties over the familiar, so if the very worst happens and you and your husband are gone, they may feel that living with your sister keeps that family connection to you, regardless of having to move to Scotland. I hope it never comes to this and that your children will be grown before they lose you both. I also hope you can come to an "in case" arrangement you're all happy with.
Posts.Title: Kids and who cares for them alesta29 apple

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2012 07:58PM Angelfalls wrote: I know what you mean, Minxie. The biggest frustration for me is that I really want to want it! But my libido just evaporated. Things have been pretty much this way for 9 years now, since my initial diagnosis at 31. So many times we've tried and failed with me ending up in tears, either because of the pain or just the sadness at the loss of the sexual being I used to be, and my poor DH concerned and comforting me. So now it's like we'd both rather avoid the trauma of it all altogether. But I'm still only 40! My friends are in their sexual prime, having babies and loving life and I couldn't even get a smear test done after 3 attempts 'cause the doc couldn't get the speculum to open up... No, not even the smallest one! It's just crap, crap and more crap! Feels better to let it out, though. Thanks for starting this thread, Angelfalls xx

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2013 07:08AM Angelfalls wrote: Hello Pat. Sorry you've had to join us, but you've come to the right place for information and support every step of the way. I was diagnosed with mets to the sternum nearly 7 years ago. It wasn't biopsied because of the risky position. I was treated with rads and an oopherectomy (my primary was ER+), before switching from Tamoxifen to Arimidex (an AI). This got me to NED quickly and kept me there for nearly 5 years, during which time I had very few SEs and carried on with my life as normal. Over the last 2 years, I've had further progression, but mostly within the chest area, and have tried a couple of chemos. I am now taking Aromasin with Afinitor. If you only have a single met in the sternum, you may be a candidate for a partial sternectomy, where they remove and replace the affected section of bone. Just another treatment option for you to be aware of. Good luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2012 07:05AM Angelfalls wrote: 1701jms, As a Stage IV hormone positive woman, I'm surprised that you're not having some form of hormone suppression anyway. I thought that was standard tx. Have I misunderstood something here? I was 35 when my cancer was found to have spread to my sternum. My onc talked through the options with me and I chose to have an ooph (to remove the main source of oestrogen and so that I could start on an AI). If I had opted for chemical suppression, I was told I would continue with that until I got to natural menopause age anyway. So my onc really wanted my ovaries shut down! Good luck with your tx.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2014 05:48AM Angelfalls wrote: I've also had a few skin mets show up recently in my chest area, with the two main lesions directly above a tumour I have in front of my sternum. (That whole sternum area was treated with rads 7 years ago... Do I see a pattern emerging?!!) No further rads have been prescribed as tx, just a change in my anti-hormonal for now with more chemo on the horizon. My onc did say that if these mets were internal, they probably wouldn't even be showing up on a CT scan, it's just that they are visible so we know they're there. But it's given us an early warning that the A/A combo had run its course.
Posts.Title: Skin Mets steelrose steelrose

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2012 07:33AM Angelfalls wrote: Yesterday was my first public appearance in a scarf. I met up with some friends in a coffee shop and oh, the stares! I hadn't remembered that from the last time! But as I got on with enjoying my friend's company, I forgot all about the people around me. I couldn't get on with a wig last time, so just used scarves and hats in soft cotton and beautiful colours. I'm in the UK where we can get a wig on prescription, but I haven't even made an appointment to get a wig this time around. Maybe I will as time goes on, but I'm in no rush to do that for now. Although an electric blue bob does appeal to me. Maybe for my step-daughter's graduation ceremony in July...
